This game shows that when you have dedicated developers that are truly passionate in what they are doing they can accomplish wonders and fantastic piece of art, just like Elden Ring, Baldur's Gate 3, The Witcher 3 and Kingdom Come Deliverance 2. I give this game a 9.5/10 and for me it's one of the best games ever made.

Wish me luck, cause after maxing achievements, and sinking 125 hours into it, I'm a ways through my second play through, and I intend to 100% everything this game has to offer (which is a lot).

I've not done a review for a game in the past, but Expedition 33 compels me to write my first. 

I largely don't know what to look for in a game, be it RPG, FPS, or even Factory Builder. Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 has shown me what I want in an RPG. Going into Expedition 33, I thought I had spoiled my self by watching a stream of the game play. Boy was I wrong. For one thing watching is very different from doing. Parries I thought would be easy to do, were some of the more difficult to pull off. And story wise, I was still rocked by it. I knew what was coming in the end, but that didn't matter.

It may be a bit presumptuous, but in my opinion, I believe Expedition 33 is worthy of Game of the Year. It's visuals, while great, aren't flawless. Timing is everything, And it's story will grab you, and keep you wanting for more, until it drops an anvil on you. 

Tomorrow comes. For those who come after.

The best game I’ve ever played. A true 10/10 masterpiece.

It’s hard to put into words how majestic Expedition 33 truly is. This might genuinely be the best game I’ve ever experienced in my life—and I don’t say that lightly. If there’s any game that deserves a perfect score, it’s this one.

Story – 10/10
The best story I’ve ever witnessed in a video game. From minute one, the intro grabs you with a hook so strong, you’re locked in. You think you know where it’s going? You don’t. It keeps surprising you at every turn, and every moment feels meaningful.

Characters – 10/10
Every character feels alive, real, and unforgettable. You care deeply about them, and their development throughout the journey is nothing short of masterful.

World/Atmosphere – 10/10
The worldbuilding and ambiance are flawless. Every area feels handcrafted with love, packed with detail and emotional weight.

Combat – 10/10
Turn-based combat doesn’t get better than this. It’s strategic, rewarding, stylish, and perfectly balanced. Probably the best of its kind.

Music – 10/10 (or more)
If I could rate the music higher than 10, I would. It’s an absolute masterpiece on its own—moving, epic, and unforgettable. I’ve found myself listening to the soundtrack outside the game just to relive the emotions.

This is one of those once-in-a-generation titles. I haven’t felt something like this since I first played Zelda: Ocarina of Time on the N64 as a kid. Expedition 33 isn’t just a game—it’s an experience I’ll carry with me forever.

Thank you to everyone who made this. You created something truly magical.
2025 masterpiece. It's going to win all the game-of-the-year awards.

A phenomenal game. The Sandfall devs wanted to make a game for the gamers after seeing what AAA developers have turned into, and they succeeded.  99/100 for me, and that 1% is only because the graphics are a bit glitchy with hair.  I can live with that.

The game is very cerebral if you want it to be. It was great to guess what was actually happening until the big reveal in Act 2. The villains are three-dimensional and have valid motives. One of the main characters has extreme flaws.  Everyone has their own form of trauma.  There are multiple layers and metaphors in the plot which are sparking so many debates online about which is the "good" and the "bad" ending. Spoiler: It's neither.  Despite that, it didn't leave a bitter feeling when I finished. I cried nonstop throughout the game and felt catharsis with the heavy topics, but I laughed so hard at the lighter humor.  The writers were fantastic at finding the balance.

It's not a turn-based game in the slightest, and yet it is.  You can make it easier if you want that kind of thing, or you can make it harder if you like to punish yourself with Souls' like games. As a blend of Final Fantasy, Nier, Souls/Bloodborne, and SO many other classic hits, this game is going to be hands down the GoTY.  

Final Fantasy X has been my favorite game since it came out, but after 20+ years, it finally met its match.  I can't wait for what Sandfall has planned in the future.

I am so sad I will never get to experience this game for the first time again and let me tell you why:

I went into this game about a day or so after release. I remember seeing a trailer once a while ago but the first steam trailer I'm hearing the narration of Jennifer English and the overall premise of the game, I figure why not. I am going to school to learn game development and art for a little context as to why this game interested me so much because of the overall visuals, voice castings, the subtle facial animations, the music and style of game, I just said fuck it and went in blind.

And I was so happy I did!

Every new combat was something unique in their design with interesting combat patterns relevant to the world you found them in. At first I began in expert mode because, how bad could it be :) I turned it off after losing to a practice enemy. BUT! After understanding the parry mechanics and how the game operated with windows of time to parry and dodge and returned to Expert mode, it made the combat all the more rewarding when counterattacking! I felt visually and mechanically rewarded so nicely when I learned the rhythms that it kept me hooked. I will say, I also felt so pissed off sometimes but that made it all the more satisfying to beat a boss.

You quickly discover the music that accompanies the game and the cut scenes and for the first time listening, you just kind of lose yourself to how hard some of those songs HIT. And they hit hard and fast.

The story is also so beautiful in the nuances of how we, as people, process grief. That is all I will say about that. Try not to spoil yourself and enjoy the journey. The characters are all unique in how they have processed in the world they live. Love them or not, they're undeniably interesting in how they contribute to the story.

To note: there are things that could be improved, don't get me wrong. However, a majority of that is just QOL features in which, since me posting this, they've already addressed a few problems and I hope they will continue to in the future, at least the major ones :)

Every Frame A Painting

“Expedition 33” will not be for everyone. The mechanics will be divisive for some (i.e., the hybrid reactive/action game elements present during some of combat, with the more traditional turn-based combat at play for skill selection and item use). For others, the aesthetics may be a turn-off (i.e., the look, ‘feel’ and sound). What could turn most people away lay in the narrative department, though. 

“Expedition 33” is one of the darkest fantasy stories I’ve ever engaged with and not simply for its superficial premise of stopping the Paintress from continuing her slow but inevitable eradication of civilization. Its overt exploration of grief, loss and family are handled deftly but unapologetically, thus are absolutely brutal in presentation and delivery. This is one of the few games I’ve played that has required me to at times put down the controller and walk away due to the intensity of the emotional impact in certain sections of the story (“The Last of Us” and “Mass Effect 3” did the same).

If you can accept all of that, what you get is a game which unflinchingly examines difficult topics with grace, respect and a level of depth and consideration unknown to most entertainment media, full stop. The story will make you laugh and cry, fill you with despair, inspire you with hope. The visuals are gorgeous and at times disturbing. The game play is phenomenal (and I’m glad the game came out now, since I’m wondering how much longer players will continue to be enamored with mechanics reliant on parry/rhythm). The soundtrack is magnificent and moving. And all of it, ALL OF IT, the story, the music, the characters, the visuals, is so layered that it will remain on your mind long after you’ve finished it. Days or possibly weeks later, you’ll make another connection or have another realization. It’s deep. Deep enough to border on profound. 

I could spend another thousand words trying to convey how wonderful, beautiful and important this game is only to come up short at the end. Instead, I will say this: “Clair Obscur: Expedition 33” is not only one of the best games I have ever played, it is one of the most powerful and poignant pieces of media I have ever interacted with. It is a shining example of games as art and playing through it was a privilege I will not soon forget.

 Merci, Sandfall, pour votre chef d’oeuvre. Je ne serai plus le meme.

“Expedition 33” gets an emphatic ‘yes’ from me. So many paint-stained, tear-streaked thumbs up. 10/10. Recommended for: gamers who like music; turn-based devotees looking for some action to spice up the genre; action players wanting to dip their toes in turn-based waters; adventurous souls brave enough to feel (provided you have no existing trauma around the issues being plumbed). PLAY. THIS. GAME.

After 37 hours of play, Expedition 33 is a contender for my favorite game of all time, and I can't recommend it highly enough.

From an aesthetic standpoint, the visuals are gorgeous, and the score works perfectly within the narrative to set a melancholic tone throughout as the characters navigate a world ruled by death.

The narrative is gripping, causing the player to develop an emotional connection to the characters and their plight almost instantly. The twist at the end reframes the entire story and central conflict in a way that gives it massive replayability, if only to see the entire story from the beginning with a new perspective.

The combat can be challenging at times, especially when encountering a new enemy or learning a new mechanic - but that makes mastering it all the more satisfying when you finally defeat that difficult boss.

This game is an absolute steal at $50 for its quality and length of content. 37 hours in, I'm still on my first playthrough, working through what feels like probably another twenty hours worth of end-game content before I plan to immediately go back and play through it again. This accomplishment by a tiny indie studio is a massive rebuke to the bloated AAA studios that ship unfinished, low-quality games and have the audacity to charge $70 for them. 

I don't think I've ever written a game review before, but felt compelled to do so for this one. All I can say is: Play Expedition 33; yes, it's that good.

[h1]  [b] 10/10 [/b] [/h1]

SUMMARY
Expedition 33 has some of the most passionate art design I've seen in a video game. It fixes many problems I personally have with turned based games adding engaging real time components to make even the simple battles feel fun. Additionally its simplification of JRPG systems such as having only a few reusable consumables and a streamlined perk and skill system make building your party feel much less daunting compared to games in the same genre. Combined with a great character-driven story, exceptional voice acting, and an insanely good score, it’s easy to overlook the games few flaws such as some underwhelming side content and limited skill selection. Expedition 33 is a near masterpiece and the creativity of its environments and world makes this game worth playing alone.

POSITIVES
-Some of the most visually stunning and creative environments I have ever laid eyes on in a video game
-Amazing enemy variety and boss design
-Great character-driven story with phenomenal voice acting
-Fixes lots of complaints I usually have with turn-based games, with real-time battles, and simple reusable consumables
-Streamlined progression system compared to other JRPGs that allows for decent build variety
-Animation quality from cutscenes to attacks were fluid and very well done making very memorable experiences
-The music genuinely had me tweaking at how good it was

NEGATIVES
-Some areas of the game were pretty disappointing to explore as their design was stunning but lacked any substantial content
-Quality of life for sorting through perks and lack of a load out system
-Limited skill selections with most characters only having around 20 skills, with many of them falling off in the late game
First game that managed to suck me in ever since last of us 1. Absolutely amazing! 10000/10

i havent finished the game yet, but i dont need to in order to say that expedition 33 is a modern masterpiece
it has amazing visuals, amazing gameplay, an actually intriguing story, and comes with arguably one of the best soundtracks ive EVER listened to in my life, up there with final fantasy 14's (Une vie à peindre is peak video game music), it all just comes together so well to create a rare gem in modern gaming that you HAVE to experience, even if you're not typically a fan of turn based games, because it does in fact have dodging and parrying in real time (which is incredibly satisfying to master by the way, especially on expert), has weak spots on enemies that you actually need to aim and shoot at (which can actually change how some enemies work!) and combat overall just feels fluid, somehow?

of course i do like turn based games, so i might be biased, but id still recommend giving it a go regardless of whether you like them or not, because you might miss out on one of the best releases in the last few years
definitely going to be 2025's uncontested game of the year
